pros: Great community hospital where you feel like family.

pros: There was plenty of gloves and the patients were a GOD SEND.
cons: Working there was a NIGHTMARE. Toxic environment. Rude nasty mean nurses. Patients were great. I've been gone for sometime and it's still a horrible place to work. It wasn't me. I knew that.

pros: They offer a Residency Program for New Graduates
cons: Lots of favoritism, extremely hostile environment. Boss rewards the lazy and overlooks peoples hard work. Charge Nurses doesnt help, sucks up to the boss and writes people up all day. Next thing you know, you get called to the office being belittled by the boss instead of giving constructive criticism of how you can better yourself as an employer. Also, if something was the go wrong between you and a patient. Goodluck, because management will take the patients side over yours. People you work with CNA and RN’s are clicky and if they found out you're doing better than them, they will insult you. Oh yea, they pay you peanuts with cent raises every year while giving you unsafe ratios. They dont care about you or your license. Do not work here!! Worse place of all time!!

job_title: Registered Nurse in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Very professional great nursing car
cons: Long hours many days together

review_title: HIGH turnover - DANGEROUS nurse/pt ratios - DIRTY FACILITY
pros: Better pay than Sentara, and I'm fairly positive that's the ONLY positive at this facility
cons: All the extra classes and tests and "sit-in" days on specific units, there's never enough education but they take it WAY overboard with tests and retesting, etc. Management and second in command both new, never on floor to assist staff/charge nurse when we ALL have a full 6 pt load (including the charge nurse) and that happened DAILY. NEVER enough people working, I know nursing is a short-staffed nightmare most places but this was ridiculous. DIRTY practices, on my first day watched a MD enter a pt room, dirty-handed pulled a JP drain from a pt, threw it in the regular garbage (no biohazard!) and walk out of room only to enter the next patient's room to do the SAME EXACT THING. No exaggeration, at least 75% of my patients were repeat, all post-surgical infections (and I could only last 3.5 months there!!!) I would never, ever in my life work for or send any one to this hospital.

pros: Great place to ear experience
cons: the sadness that comes with the occupation

pros: Most employees are really friendly..
cons: You will ALWAYS be underpaid and get a bunch of excuses from management that you're paid "competitively" compared to surrounding hospitals which is in flat out untrue!  They always make you feel that what you do is never enough but give "empty praise" to try to keep you motivated for what you do.   It is not a working environment favorable to new grad nurses because there is no real education that goes on there.  I've seen new grad nurses being oriented by new nurses with less than 1 yr experience or by experienced nurses who just aren't that good which you will learn bad habits and practices which can get you in trouble later on and don't expect any mercy!  There are a LOT of brown nosers in regular staff and management who will do anything to make themselves look good to succeed.  So don't be fooled by all friendly faces.  Don't expect to advance.....opportunities are LIMITED and usually go to the "buddies" of management.  Travel nurses better beware!  You will get all the crappy assignments and as many admissions as they can give you!

job_title: Clinical Nurse Manager in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Family oriented.  Independent hospital.  Out patient pharmacy with great prices.  Clinical ladder for the bedside nurses. New CEO , CMO, CNO.  Trying to bring the organization to the fore front and improve the quality of care they give
cons: Independent hospital. C suite is heavy and not always supportive.  Newest c suite is making big changes and it can be frustrating to the staff.  Not all communication is clear.  Information is not always passed down from the top to the frontline.  Nursing forgets that there are nurses in the hospital that are not at the bedside and need to be treated like they are valuable.  Benefits are expensive with high deductibles. Started a clinical ladder which is great for bedside nurses but those not at bedside there is really no chance for advancement.

pros: Flexibility.  The gym membership is nice but expensive for employees.  The cafeteria looks nice and is clean for the most part. The main entrance looks amazing with the staircase.
cons: Upper management has no idea what it actually going on in the hospital. C suite never seen on the units, can't remember the last time even saw one of them outside of the suite.  Back stabbing by all from managers up and even among the staff.  No transparency and no where to go to report anything. No accountability throughout the organization. Finger pointers all around. I have been thrown under the bus so many times I think my next job should be a bus mechanic. Losing many great employees because you won't let them transfer to another unit so they are leaving the organization.  Such a shame and a waste.

pros: The employees are dedicated to making the patient experience what it should be. New CEO has been making positive changes and moving business in the right direction. He has a big mess to clean up from his predecessor but plans are in place to improve all aspects of the organization.  I would have stayed if I could have, the future looks bright!
cons: Pay is not very competitive unless to push the issue. Administrated staff who have been there a long time have no assertiveness. You have to speak for yourself and be confident to get what you need!

job_title: STaff Registered Nurse in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Small hospital with a community base.
cons: When I started here almost 20 years ago, this was a great place to work and it was hard to get a job here.  Since Mr Buckley left. It has gone slowly downhill until it is a terrible place to work.  The only safe position is as a staff nurse with no involvement in anything.  Unless you have friends in the right places, and stay on their good sides, don't try to advance - you'll only be a target.  I used to be proud to say I work here....  Now, its embarrassing at the number of patient complaints about the care they receive.  I'm just waiting for retirement ....

review_title: I have been employed at CRMC for some time now, and overall it has been a good experience.
pros: It is a stand alone community hospital.  Many really good employees and upper managment.
cons: There is a strong good ol boy network.  Promotions not based on experience or results, but based seemingly on relationships.  Overall, I have been lucky and have worked for a few really good people.  Working in such a tight knit organization can sometimes be difficult, as it is sometimes difficult to fit in.  Senior management seems to not recognize brown nosed employess and will promote them a ridiculaous number of times.

review_title: It is a pleasant place to work.
pros: Independent hospitals offer more of a sense of community.  Everyone was friendly, and I really felt that patient care was priority.
cons: They pay a little bit less than hospitals in surrounding areas, but it is still worth taking a pay cut to work at this hospital opposed to others in the area.

pros: Great team work amongst staff and non-executive leaders
cons: It use to be a 5 star employer

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN, MSN in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Administration listens, unit managers awesome, co-workers amazing! Small community hospital with caring employees, hoping for Magnet status within the next 5 years. Great leadership! Clinical ladder opportunities, tuition reimbursement, many perks and a turkey at Thanksgiving! We are starting a major renovation and will hopefully be completed in the next 2-3 years.
cons: medical insurance is not so great, but we are about to start with a new company 2020, so we will see.

pros: Benefits package is decent. Good community. Great volunteer program. Pets are a great asset to lift spirits for both staff and patients.
cons: I have tears in my eyes writing my thoughts into words. I have seen the hospital that I have loved for many years fall from grace into a very dark and scandalous time. There is a black cloud over CRMC. Things are not getting better for us. We used to be the place to come and work. We had fun. We celebrated.This executive team does not demonstrate the values of the organization. The decision to demote leaders and to lay off staff a week before Thanksgiving and two weeks before a new CEO arrives is questionable. I hear that they are terminating some leaders under bogus reasons. Reasons that the executive team members could lose their jobs for. If the Board Authority has the ultimate say, then step in already and do things the right way. What I find that is most troubling is that all of the leaders that were laid off or demoted were women. When you speak to anyone here everyone knows of the constant failure of this executive team. There decisions are based on the way a person feels without substantial evidence. I am tired of losing the great ones and being stuck with this mess. Turnover is almost 20% which is double national average but let us not talk about that. I go to a nursing forum to be told that "we have hired 100 nurses". Where are they? People are leaving as fast as you hire them. When I say that everyone I know is actively seeking employment elsewhere, I mean everyone I know. Should tell you something. If you are not a white male, you will not advance. I also believe that there is a disproportionately higher salary range for our white male leaders compared to female leaders. Diversity has never been their top priority here. They want everyone to say what they want them to say. If you are not willing to do that, you are immediately identified as a problem. Innovation is what they tell us. There is pockets of innovation but they are not able to get us there and they haven't for a long time.

review_title: One of the worst employers I’ve ever had
pros:
It’s a paycheck, barely.
Convenient location.
cons: Too many to list!  Management is absent in daily operations!  HR has no clue what’s going on in the departments they “support”.  Long-time employees are given carte-blanche to bulldoze new employees.  Newer staff is given more tasks so that older employees can slack and do what they want, when they want. Management was made aware of this, and it was brushed under the rug.  HR was then made aware, and though they were shocked (especially when given proof), Management did not allow any action to be taken.

pros: Very nice staff, lots of people with smiles on their faces. Less strict than some of the other area hospitals. Independent hospital with less "corporate" feel and more "local" feel.
cons: As it's independent from the Sentara Mega-hospital corporation that dominates the area, CRMC is constantly on the defensive. Pay rate is less than Sentara and there hasn't been a bonus in a while.

pros: The hard working employees, some dedicated physicians, housekeeping, and the community. Some of their patient services are actually decent. The caring and kind volunteers. I wish I could say them being independent is good but it really has not benefited the community as well as it could. There can be some much more potential for the community and they lack innovation.
cons: For starters the unsafe nurse patient ration. Nurses are set up to compromise patient safety because of the staffing situation. The unsettlingly reality is they do not care. You won't see your manager or leadership team coming to lend a helping hand or address the situation head on because they lack experience, knowledge, and solidarity to lead. The recently compensated them with a cost of living raise and other incentives but everyone is still miserable. They people they are now managing to hire in are replacing the people who are leaving. They have more agency nurses than I can comprehend. Good nurses are leaving that are skilled and have experience that they need to mentor the inexperienced. I put my resignation letter in and after several years there you would think my manager would ask why or a call from HR. That isn't the case at CRMC. They offer a residency program for new nurses and they aren't receiving the knowledge or experience they deserve. I have witnessed them listening to miserable nurses, unhappy, tired, diminishing morale, unsafe practices being learned, short cuts , unrelastic expectations and absent management and leadership. What I have witnessed since the CEO left is a hospital that is spiraling down. Hospital leaders overwhelmed and trying to stay financially viable, so they are myopically focused on bottom line on which their survial depends. They could onl see the true impact on the employees, how careless they have been, and what a bunch of idiots they look like.

job_title: Radiology Charge Nurse in Chesapeake, VA
pros:
Small community hopsital and supports the community.  
Leadership is concern about the welfare of the patients by seeking ways to improve care to meet Joint Commission standards.
cons:
Management doesn't always pass information down successfully in a timely manner.
Patients have difficult finding their way through the hospital.

pros: I worked with some of the most kind-hearted, generous and family oriented people. I would have loved to stay at CRMC for a long time but just could not do it.
cons: I left CRMC approximately four months ago. For the first time in my career, I did not want to come to work. I love what I do. But something happened when leadership changed. Everyone was on edge. We were being asked to do things that were not "right". I was asked to put in codes and charges for patients that I know were not done. Many of my friends are nurses and are working so hard without help. These nurses are not complainers. They work hard for 12 and 14 hours and come home in tears because they hope that they have done everything they could to provide great care. Recently, I spoke to a nurse on the 6th floor. She has been there almost 6 years. She told me that she had 9 patients and no care partner. This is the telemetry unit. She said that there manager doesn't care. What is worse, she said that their CNO doesn't care. In all honesty, I was never going to say a thing about what I have personally witnessed as illegal and unethical practices but I can't continue to watch my community hospital that I was born in just continue to crumble. What kind of responsible employee would I be if I didn't say something? I should have spoken up for change while I was there but too many of our great employees were asked to leave or placed in different positions because of having an "opinion".

review_title: Mid-management great,  with some changes put in place it would be the best place to work.
pros: Sense of family environment with 2000+ employees, friendly place, mid-management are wonderful to work for.
cons: Resources are scarce to effectively perform, workflows and process changes are very difficult to implement,

review_title: Bullying, inconsistent, poor Leadership at all levels
pros: If you are a critical care nurse you may make a few extra dollars there than with the competition because of incentive pay that is only offered to those areas, base pay is competitive with area. Friendly and competent frontline caregivers despite all the challenges. It is a great starting point for new graduate nurses, you will learn time management and resilience.
cons: Top heavy inconsistent leadership at ALL levels. Directors and VPs care nothing for the frontline staff, they are all worried about keeping their jobs at all costs. Leadership turns over frequently and often not for the good. Strong leaders and frontline staff are pushed out of the organization to make way for "yes men" who will do what they are told. Overall turnover rates for staff is much higher than national average. This is due to lack of support for the frontline. Leadership promises lower ratios but never makes good on those promises. Unit specialties change frequently contributing to turnover. They have difficulty recruiting experienced staff so the skill mix is very unbalanced, especially on the floors and at night. Their leadership promises programs that help recruit and retain staff but don't actually follow through with them. They have promised a clinical ladder for several years but they never seem to have the money to actually do it. They are too busy trying to build programs like the heart program to invest in their staff. Raises are few and far between so if  you are expecting to work your way up be ready to be disappointed.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Chesapeake, VA
pros: I enjoy the flexibility of my schedule.
cons: very poor management. frequent cutbacks in staffing. working dangerously short staffed. incentive pay was done away with last year.my hourly wage went down $2.50 yet company pays multimillions in upgrades to hospital.

review_title: CMS should audit all scheduling, billing, and financial aide practices.
pros: Employee health benefits if using Chesapeake Regional services.
cons: Administration and Compliance Officer ignoring concerns of billing practices. Schedules procedures for infusion therapy and imaging before authorizations are obtained thus causing undue higher costs to patients when insurance doesn't cover the meds or services.

review_title: Working there caused me to have some of the worse years of my life.
pros: The housekeeping staff was very nice.
cons: My boss was disengaged and not knowledgeable of the field.  Some of the physicians were rude and vindictive.

pros: Our rehab director still works the floors and understands what a therapist can encounter each day.
